article.title: PreCog: Improving Crowdsourced Data Quality Before Acquisition

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the primary disadvantage of relying solely on post-hoc quality control for text acquisition in crowdsourcing?
choices: Increased cost and latency
Lower overall text quality
Inability to identify all low-quality text
Difficulty in implementing automated quality checks

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the beige component in Figure 2 represent in the context of crowdsourced text acquisition?
choices: Crowd worker training
Data quality estimation by additional workers
Pre-hoc quality control integrated into the task interface
Post-hoc quality control mechanisms

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the core function of the "Predict" stage in the Segment-Predict-Explain pattern?
choices: Dividing the text into grammatically correct sentences
Identifying the sentiment expressed in each segment
Estimating the quality of each segment and the overall text
Extracting relevant keywords and topics from the text

multiple_choice_question.text: What key advantage does Precog offer compared to traditional form validation for crowdsourced data acquisition?
choices: It simply rejects invalid input with error messages.
It requires extensive coding from developers for basic validation.
It provides iterative feedback and interface adjustments to help workers improve data quality before submission.
It solely relies on generic error messages for all types of data constraints.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the primary function of the "Model Store" component in the Precog architecture?
choices: It stores the raw text data collected from crowd workers.
It caches the trained document-level and segment-level quality prediction models.)
It manages the user interface elements for providing feedback to workers.
It handles the payment and task assignment for crowd workers.
